Description: Species epithet (it could include variety or subspecies)
Author of species name as Flora of Virginia (2012)
Species code used at SCBI, four characters refers to first two letters of genus and first two letters of species
Most common canopy position for individuals within a species (emergent crown, canopy, understory, shrub layer), commonly used as a proxy for light availability.
General plant classification: tree, small tree, shrub
Indicates if the plant naturally occurs in Virginia or if it was introduced (source Flora of Virginia, 2012)
Common habitat where species grow naturally (source Flora of Virginia, 2012)
Most common successional stage of a plant species (pioneer, early successional, late succesional, opportunistic, etc). Source Forest Service, USDA (https://www.feis-crs.org/feis/faces/index.xhtml).

Degree to which a plant species is adapted to arid or drought conditions: drought-resistant ( species are able to tolerate prolonged periods of drynes)  or drough-intolerant (various sources, https://www.feis-crs.org/feis/faces/index.xhtml, https://www.nycgovparks.org/greening/greenbelt-native-plant-center/garden-species-lists/garden-drought)
Indicates how palatable a plant species is to deer, the more palatable a plant is, the harder to establish; the less palatable a plant is, the easier to grow (various sources)

Sexual reproduction type: Androdioecious (a species that bears only staminate flowers on some plants but staminate and pistillate flowers or bisexual flowers on other plants); Andromonoecious (a species that bears staminate and bisexual flowers on the same plant); Dioecious (a species that bears only functionally staminate flowers on some plants and only functionally pistillate flowers on other plants); Gynodioecious (a species that bears pistillate flowers on some plants and bisexual flowers or staminate flowers as well as pistillate flowers on other plants); Gynomonoecious (a species that bears pistillate flowers and bisexual flowers on same plants); Homoecious (a species that bears only bisexual flowers on each plant); Monoecious (plant that bears male staminate and female-pistillate flowers on the same plant); Polygamodioecious (a species that bears (male) staminate and bisexual (perfect) flowers on some plants and female (pistillate) and bisexual flowers on other plants (Glosary: http://sweetgum.nybg.org/science/glossary/, plant data: various sources)
Fruit type (samaras, drupe, etc) -source Flora of Virginia, 2012
Dipersal vector could be biotic (animals) or abiotic (wind, gravity) - various sources

The conservation status per species as categories from the IUCN Red List: Least Concern: populations stable or taxon that do not qualify as threatened. Near threatened: taxon close to qualifying as threatened category in the near future). Vulnerable: A taxon considered to be facing a high risk of extinction in the wild. Endangered: A taxon considered to be facing a very high risk of extinction in the wild. Critically endangered: A taxon considered to be facing an extremely high risk of extinction in the wild. (IUCN Standards and Petitions Subcommittee, 2017):
Author and year of main reference used for any ecological descriptor
